content.prompt: The spheres are isolated from all other objects, and sphere X is then released from rest. The student says that, assuming the gravitational forces between the spheres are negligible, the kinetic energy of sphere X just before it hits sphere Y can be determined by multiplying the electric force exerted on sphere X at its original position by the distance it moves. Is the student correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because force times distance equals work, and the work equals the change in kinetic energy.
Yes, because the electric force is the only force exerted if gravity is negligible.
No, because the calculation of work must take into account the fact that the force on sphere X changes as it moves.
No, because the change in kinetic energy can only be determined from the change in potential energy of the system.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
